docs.snippet: The demolition of earthquake-damaged ramps to the old Central Freeway at Franklin and Gough Streets cleared the way for a thriving shopping strip on Hayes Street....
docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1992, earthquake-damaged ramps to the old Central Freeway at Franklin and Gough Streets in San Francisco were torn down, opening up views from the heart of Hayes Valley clear to City Hall. The demolition cleared the way for a thriving shopping strip on Hayes Street, once bisected by the freeway and plagued by crime. Simultaneously, residents living in the shadow of the area's other elevated freeway ramp, on Fell Street, lobbied for its removal and replacement by an alternative Parisian-style thoroughfare: the brand-new Octavia Boulevard. This summer, the city inaugurated a recreational space, a 275-foot-long tree-lined stretch called Hayes Green Park, just another sign that once-seedy Hayes Valley had arrived.
docs.abstract: Bonnie Tsui travel article on revitalization of Hayes Valley, once run-down area of San Francisco, Calif, after earthquake-damaged ramps to old Central Freeway were torn down; photo; map (M)

docs.snippet: WHERE to go for a holiday whether a week-end trip or a month's motor tour-does not have to  be decided by guesswork. Scattered over the country are hundreds of information centers which make a business of answering questions about accommodations, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHERE to go for a holiday whether a week-end trip or a month's motor tour-does not have to be decided by guesswork. Scattered over the country are hundreds of information centers which make a business of answering questions about accommodations, rates, points of interest and recreation opportunities for their particular areas. And the service is free for the asking.

byline.original: By PAUL SHOWERSGreat Northern RailwayJaskulswi from MonkmeyerGreat Northern Railway

docs.snippet: Every now and then, in a moment of uncommon quiet, the distinctive wail of a rural love song rises from some unseen corner of Bangkok, and the urge to get out of town becomes overwhelming.   The sound of upcountry music, the rare scent of fresh ea...
docs.lead_paragraph: Every now and then, in a moment of uncommon quiet, the distinctive wail of a rural love song rises from some unseen corner of Bangkok, and the urge to get out of town becomes overwhelming. The sound of upcountry music, the rare scent of fresh earth or flowers, or the sight of hill tribe people in traditional dress squatting in front of a video shop are reminders that beyond this polluted, traffic-clogged city, there is another Thailand. It can be found in almost any direction: north to the cool mountains, south along an endless seacoast, west into peaceful river valleys, northeast into the majestic world of the Mekong. Although the number of tourists traveling beyond Bangkok from Japan, Hong Kong and Europe is increasing, this is a country that is mostly still off the tourist track, while easily manageable for independent travelers. Visitors willing to put up with some fairly basic hotels and eating places enjoy in return remarkably varied scenery and the atmosphere of a nation reflecting Sinetic, Indic and Malay cultures, yet always very Thai. That means Thai (or Chinese-Thai) food in every town, and the ubiquitous enthusiasm with which Thais try to please visitors.

byline.original: By BARBARA CROSSETTE; Barbara Crossette is the Bangkok bureau chief of The New York Times

docs.snippet: NASSAU, Bahamas -- This coral - studded British island resort is back in business again as a major winter-vacation center. The hotels and nightclubs are open, the tourists are back sunning themselves and the colony is out to make up for the losses...
docs.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas -- This coral - studded British island resort is back in business again as a major winter-vacation center. The hotels and nightclubs are open, the tourists are back sunning themselves and the colony is out to make up for the losses in its $38,924,000 annual holiday trade which were incurred during last month's general strike.

headline.main: NASSAU'S COME-BACK; Resort Trade Regaining Peak-Season Pace

docs.snippet: IT is amazing but true. I am in the riverside town of Vang Vieng, Laos, standing on a bamboo bridge that spans the 150-yard breadth of the Nam Song, yet I am reminded, of all things, of the Garden State Parkway. This is because the man barring my ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is amazing but true. I am in the riverside town of Vang Vieng, Laos, standing on a bamboo bridge that spans the 150-yard breadth of the Nam Song, yet I am reminded, of all things, of the Garden State Parkway. This is because the man barring my way is demanding a toll: 1,000 kips for me, plus the same for my rented mountain bike. I look the bridge up and down; it is rickety, to say the least, maybe five feet wide, sagging with the accumulated weight of pedestrians past. Its surface is missing substantial patches in places, creating treacherous bamboo potholes.
docs.abstract: Geronimo Madrid travel article on trip to Vang Vieng, Laos; photos; maps (L)

headline.main: A Laos Huck Finn Would Love

docs.snippet: Members of the House of Representatives accepted nearly 4,000 trips in 1989 and 1990 that were paid for by corporations or trade groups, with Chicago the top destination, according to a report made public today.   Three Democrats, Patricia Schroed...
docs.lead_paragraph: Members of the House of Representatives accepted nearly 4,000 trips in 1989 and 1990 that were paid for by corporations or trade groups, with Chicago the top destination, according to a report made public today. Three Democrats, Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania and Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, were listed as taking the most trips, according to the report, "They Love to Fly, And It Shows," by Public Citizen, a research organization founded by the consumer advocate Ralph Nader.

headline.main: Consumer Group Criticizes Travel by House Members

docs.snippet: LEAD: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some s...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

headline.main: Ten Escapes to the Exotic: Thailand
